Direct conversion of glucose into acetylfurans via C−C bond cleavage over Cs promoted Mo-based catalyst Wei Wang Writing – original draft Software Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation a Rui Zhang Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources Funding acquisition Conceptualization a ⁎ Jiaqing Li Software Investigation a Huai Liu Methodology a Wenlong Jia Methodology a Junhua Zhang Methodology a Dan Li Resources Methodology b Lincai Peng Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources Project administration Funding acquisition a ⁎ a BiomassChem Group, Faculty of Chemical Engineering, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, 650500, PR China BiomassChem Group Faculty of Chemical Engineering Kunming University of Science and Technology Kunming 650500 PR China aBiomassChem Group, Faculty of Chemical Engineering, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming, 650500, PR China b Dan Li - Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Technology, Ministry of Education, College of Chemistry, Sichuan University, Chengdu, 610064, PR China Dan Li - Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Technology Ministry of Education College of Chemistry Sichuan University Chengdu 610064 PR China bDan Li - Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Technology, Ministry of Education, College of Chemistry, Sichuan University, Chengdu, 610064, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Furans are important scaffolds with applications in pharmaceuticals, polymers synthesis and biofuels. The direct production of new types of furans from glucose is therefore significant but remains a great challenge. Herein, we report a facile strategy to produce acetylfurans directly from glucose over MoCs-SiO2, with an increase in yield from 35.8 % to 81.4 % compared with pristine Mo-SiO2 due to the facilitated C−C bond cleavage of glucose. The incorporation of Cs improved the dispersion of Mo species, induced the formation of partially reduced Mo, increased the Lewis acidity and glucose adsorption of the catalyst, and thus shifting the reaction selectivity from C−C coupling to cleavage. Kinetic studies further demonstrated the positive contribution of Cs as a promoter in lowering the activation energy of C−C bond cleavage. This study provides a promising strategy to broaden the range of furanic compounds derived from glucose for product-oriented biorefineries. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Carbohydrates Furanic compounds C−C bond cleavage In situ transformation Mo-based catalyst Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Great research efforts have been devoted to explore resources for the production of chemicals, fuels and materials due to the growing demand of modern society [1–3]. Biomass as the only renewable source of organic carbon is generally addressed as a promising alternative to alleviate the dependence on petroleum-based resources and the adverse environmental impact [4]. Glucose, as the cheapest and most abundant monosaccharide that is readily available from agricultural waste, has been extensively studied for the manufacture of various fine chemicals mainly through C−C and C–O bond cleavage strategies [5,6], which were also widely employed in the transformation of other biomass-related molecules [7,8]. Given its high availability and rich functionality, the development of glucose-based value chains for carbon-neutral end products is of particular interest towards a sustainable future. Furans and their derivatives are a class of oxygen-containing five-membered heterocyclic organic small molecules, which are prevalent in the structure of biologically active compounds, and thus are important drug precursors [9–13]. They are also widely used in the synthesis of polymer materials, such as furan resins and epoxy resins [14–17]. In addition, furanic compounds can also be used to synthesize photochromic molecules, food additives and biofuels [18]. For now, the preparation of furans from sugars has mainly focused on 5-hydroxymethylfurfural and furfural through direct dehydration [4]. Meanwhile, a variety of derivatives like 2,5-diformylfuran [19], 2,5-dimethylfuran [20], 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid [21], 2,5-furandimethanol [22], furfuryl acid and furfuryl alcohol [23,24] can be obtained by further upgrading of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural and furfural. However, the synthesis of other types of furanic compounds directly from monosaccharides are rarely reported, while the separation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural and furfural . The new reactions and organic transformation routes to broaden the biomass conversion paths is always highly needed [25]. Thus, the exploration of catalytic conversion pathways to broaden the scope of furanic compounds from glucose is of great significance. In our previous study, a retro-aldol condensation (RAC) strategy was developed for production of value-added acetylfuranic chemicals, 2-methyl-3-acetylfuran (MAF, 20 %) and 1-(5-(1,2-dihydroxyethyl)-2methylfuran-3-yl) ethan-1-one (DMAF, 28 %). The C2 glycolaldehyde/C4 erythrose intermediates derived from the [C2 + C4] C−C bond cleavage of glucose was captured in situ by acetylacetone (acac) to form furan rings [26]. This reaction itself is intriguing because it avoids the use of expensive glycolaldehyde and erythrose as the starting material, which are not directly available from nature. Moreover, the production of C2/C4 intermediates as isolated products from abundant carbohydrates are commonly restricted with either demanding conditions or limited yield [5]. Therefore, the in situ conversion of these intermediates without separation to form different target products is a promising strategy. In addition, acac can be obtained directly from glucose via biosynthetic route [27] or via bio-based triacetic acid lactone route in almost quantitative yield [28], demonstrating its sustainability as a reagent (Fig. S1). Molybdenum (Mo)-containing compounds are commonly recognized as efficient catalysts for the epimerization of glucose to mannose, where the carbon skeleton rearrangement occurs via glucose C2−C3 bond breakage and subsequent C1−C3 bond formation in the transition state [29,30]. Given to this feature, a simple H2MoO4 catalyst was employed to catalyze the C−C bond cleavage of glucose under mild conditions [26]. Nevertheless, the total carbon yield of MAF and DMAF was limited to 48 %. This could be largely attributed to the intrinsic high activation energy for the RAC of glucose even with ammonium metatungstate as a catalyst (∼160 kJ/mol) [31]. Therefore, Mo-based catalysts with enhanced C−C bond cleavage ability should be developed to increase the carbon efficiency and atom economy toward new types of furanic compounds production. The RAC of the sugars is the dominant reaction for C−C bond cleavage that can be catalysed by base sites or transition metal sites at relatively high temperatures (> 160 °C) [32]. Some base cations, such as K+, Ca2+, Ba2+ and Cs+, could accelerate the RAC process significantly [33,34]. For instance, a series of alkaline and alkaline earth metal salts of phosphotungstic acid (HPW) were developed by Liu et al. for the production of 1,1,2-trialkoxyethanes from biomass-derived sugars. It was found that the catalytic activity was positively correlated with the alkalinity of the metal elements, while Cs2HPW showed the best activity for the conversion of glucose to 1,1,2-trialkoxyethanes via selective C−C bond cleavage at 180 °C. The yield of 1,1,2-triethoxyethane increased from 19 % to 72.6 % compared to the pristine HPW catalyst [35]. Inspired by the above works, we herein reported the conversion of glucose into new type of furanic compounds MAF and DMAF via Cs-promoted Mo-SiO2 catalysts, where the in situ nucleophilic addition of acac with C2 glycolaldehyde/C4 erythrose intermediates could in turn drive the C−C bond cleavage of glucose toward high carbon efficiency. The effect of the introduction of Cs on the catalytic performance of Mo-SiO2 was evaluated by systematic experiment investigations, catalyst characterizations and kinetic studies. The main reaction pathway of glucose transformation into value-added furanic building blocks was proposed and discussed according to the catalytic performance using mannose as the substrate. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Glucose, mannose, acetylacetone (acac), Cs2CO3, KCl, NaCl, MgCl2·6H2O, BaCl2·2H2O, LiCl·H2O, SiO2 (surface area around 200 m2/g) and Cu(NO3)2·3H2O were purchased from Aladdin Reagent. (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O, Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, Co(NO3)2·6H2O, NiCl2·6H2O were obtained from Shanghai Macklin Reagent. Isopropanol, ethanol, dodecane, ethylacetate and petroleum ether were purchased from Rhawn Reagent. All chemicals and solvents were obtained from commercial suppliers and used as received. 2.2 Catalyst preparation All catalysts were synthesized by ultrasound-assisted wetness impregnation. For a typical procedure, 0.4 g of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O and 0.37 g of Cs2CO3 were first dissolved in distilled water containing 10 % of isopropanol and then added dropwise into 1.66 g of SiO2 support. The resulting mixture was magnetically stirred for 2 h, sonicated for 1 h, and then dried in an oven at 105 °C overnight. The solid catalyst precursor was calcined at 550 °C for 6 h under N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 2 °C·min−1 and the final product was labelled as MoCs-SiO2, where the content of Mo was maintained at 10 wt% and the molar ratio of Mo:Cs was set to 1:1. Catalysts with different molar ratio of Mo:Cs were donated as MoCsx-SiO2 (Mo/Cs = 1/x, x = 0.1, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1 and 1.5). Similarly, the other as synthesized catalysts were donated as MoM-SiO2 (Mo/M = 1/1, molar ratio), where M represents different metal elements. 2.3 General reaction procedure and product analysis All experiments were conducted in a 25 mL stainless steel autoclave equipped with magnetic stirring, where the heating and temperature was controlled by a temperature-sensing probe. For a typical run, 180 mg of glucose, 50 mg of catalyst, 5 mL of acac and 5 mL of H2O were added into the reactor. The reactor was sealed and flushed with N2 for three times and 0.5 MPa N2 was finally purged for reaction. The reactor was then emerged into a pre-heated oil bath with desired temperature for certain times at a stirring speed of 600 rpm. Upon completion, the reactor was cooled with a fan to the ambient temperature for further analysis. The recycle experiments was conducted by directly reuse the entire catalytic system. After each reaction, fresh glucose substrate (same amount as in the first run) was added into the reaction solution to continue the reaction. The yields of acetylfurans were calculated by subtracting their amounts from the previous reaction. The product MAF in organic phase were analysed by an Agilent 7820 gas chromatography (GC) equipped with a flame ionization detector. A HP-5 column (30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 μm) was employed with N2 at a flow rate of 1.0 mL·min−1 as the carrier gas. The initial oven temperature was set at 50 °C, ramped up to 90 °C at a rate of 20 °C·min−1, and then increased to 230 °C by the temperature ramp of 30 °C·min−1. The temperature of the detector was 250 °C. The analysis of DMAF and C-glycosylfuran (derived from the Garcia Gonzalez reaction of acac and glucose) in water phase were conducted on Waters 2695 high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) with an HPX-87H column (300 mm × 7.8 mm). The temperature of the column was set at 30 °C and a Waters 2487 UV detector at the wavelength of 280 nm was employed. The structure of three products were analyzed by NMR and mass spectrometry (Figs. S2–S16). 1H, 13C, 2D HSQC and HMBC NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Avance Ⅲ 400-MHz spectrometer. The calibration and analysis of spectra was conducted by using MestReNova. MAF was analyzed by Agilent 5973–6890 N GC–MS. The high-resolution electrospray-ionization mass spectra (ESI-MS) were recorded with a Bruker microTOF mass spectrometer and Waters ACQUITY UPLC Ⅰ-Class/XEVO G2-XS Qtof-MS in a positive ion mode. The amount of DMAF was determined using 5-hydroxymethylfurfural as the standard. Both purified MAF and C-glycosylfuran was used as authentic standard (followed the procedure reported by Ronaghi et al [36].). The conversion of glucose and mannose were quantified using Waters 2695 HPLC system equipped with SH1011 column (300 mm × 8 mm) and Waters 410 refractive index detector, and the column temperature was set at 55 °C. The mobile phase for both column was dilute H2SO4 (5 mmol·L−1) and the flow rate was 0.6 mL·min−1 and 0.8 mL·min−1, respectively. Data were elaborated according to calibration curves with standard glucose and mannose. The conversion of glucose and the yield of furanic products were calculated as follows: (1) Conversion of glucose ( % ) = ( 1 − moles of glucose after reaction moles of glucose before reaction ) × 100 % (2) Yield of MAF ( % ) = moles of carbon in MAF moles of carbon in glucose before reaction × 100 % (3) Yield of DMAF ( % ) = moles of carbon in DMAF moles of carbon in glucose before reaction × 100 % (4) Yield of acetylfurans ( % ) = Yield of MAF + Yield of DMAF (5) Yield of C − glycosylfuran ( % ) = moles of C − glycosylfuran formed moles of glucose before reaction × 100 % 2.4 Characterization methods Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurement was conducted on a Bruker D8 advance X-ray diffractometer with a Cu Kα radiation source at 40 kV and 30 mA over a 2 θ range of 10° to 80° at a scanning speed of 10°⋅min-1. The textural properties of the catalysts were analyzed by a JW-BK 112 surface analyzer. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis was performed on an EI Tecnai G2 joint with an INCA instrument with the accelerating voltage of 20 kV. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were recorded on a Thermo NICOLET 380 FTIR spectrometer with a resolution of 4 cm−1 and an accumulation of 32 scans. The Raman spectra were recorded with a Renishaw Raman Imaging Microprobe System equipped with a laser at 532 nm. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of the catalysts were recorded by Thermo Fisher Talos F200X with the voltage of 200 kV. The content of Mo and Cs were determined by Inductively Coupled Plasma-Optical Emission Spectroscopy (ICP-OES) and ICP-MS with Thermo Fisheri CAP 7400 and Agilent 7800, respectively. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) test was performed on a Thermo Fisher Scientific K-Alpha instrument with a 158 Al Kα radiation source. The pyridine-FTIR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Tensor 27 equipped with a vacuum cell in the wavenumber range of 1400−1700 cm−1. The sample was pressed into a wafer and activated under vacuum at 350 °C for 2 h to record the background spectrum. After cooling, the sample was then saturated with pyridine at 40 °C for 1 h. The desorption spectrum was recorded after removing the excess pyridine at 350 °C. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts The XRD patterns of the catalysts were depicted in Fig. 1 a. All tested catalysts exhibited a broad diffraction peak at 2 θ of 22.0° as shown in pure SiO2 support, which corresponded to the amorphous silica materials [37,38]. The intensity of this characteristic peak decreased with the doping of Mo and Cs. The diffraction peaks of MoO3 (PDF#35–0609) could be observed in Mo-SiO2, which was more noticeable compared with the MoCsx-SiO2 catalysts. The intensity of the diffraction peaks of MoO3 decreased as the loading amount Cs increased, and no Cs-related species could be identified even in Cs-SiO2 catalyst. This indicated that the two metals did not form specific crystalline phases and the addition of Cs resulted in a better dispersion of Mo species. The FTIR spectra of various catalysts showed similar features to SiO2 after the doping of metals (Fig. S17). However, the absorption around 3400 cm−1 was significantly reduced, which is generally attributed to the asymmetric stretching vibration of surface Si-OH [38,39], implying the success incorporation of Mo and Cs. This is consistent with the decreased intensity of the diffraction peaks of SiO2 after metal loading from XRD patterns. The textural properties of the catalysts were further analyzed. All catalyst exhibited type IV isotherms at high relative pressure (IUPAC), indicating their mesoporous feature (Fig. S18). The original SiO2 had large surface area of 210 m2·g−1 and high average pore volume of 0.94 cm3·g−1 as well as large pore size, which were decreased after the impregnation of Mo due to the blockage of pore structure (Table S1). This effect became more pronounced when the content of Cs increased, which could be ascribe to its intrinsic larger ionic radius. All MoCsx-SiO2 catalysts had relatively low surface area and pore volume, implying that the textural properties of the catalysts with different molar ratio of Mo and Cs had neglectable effects on their catalytic performance in the present study. The Raman spectra of Mo-SiO2 displayed vibration peaks at 285, 337, 375, 473, 666, 818 and 995 cm−1, which corresponded to orthorhombic MoO3 (Fig. 1b). The Raman bands at 995 and 285 cm−1 were attributed to MoO bonds, while Raman bands at 818 and 666 cm−1 were ascribed to the stretching vibration of Mo-O-Mo bridge bonds [40,41]. These characteristic peaks disappeared in MoCs-SiO2, suggesting that the addition of Cs promoted the dispersion of Mo species. This was also reflected in TEM images (Fig. 1c and d), while Mo-SiO2 showed the lattice fringe with the spacing of 0.26 nm, corresponding to the (140) plane of MoO3 (Fig. S19). In contrast, no such lattice fringe could be observed in MoCs-SiO2. In addition, Mo-SiO2 exhibited non-uniformly distributed particles with larger size and agglomeration (Fig. 1c), whereas the particles were evenly distributed in MoCs-SiO2 (Fig. 1d) and the particle size were obviously smaller. The average particle size was around 1.55 nm over MoCs-SiO2, which was smaller than that the 2.57 nm of Mo-SiO2. Furthermore, the elemental mapping image of Mo element on MoCs-SiO2 (Fig. 1f) showed better dispersion compared with Mo-SiO2 catalyst (Fig. S19), suggesting that the introduction of Cs reduced the particle size of active species and favoured the dispersion of Mo species, which in general would facilitate better catalytic performance [42]. This is also in line with the XRD and Raman results. To further investigate the influence of Cs doping, the chemical states of Mo were analysed. The XPS spectra of Mo 3d and Cs 3d were presented in Fig. 2 a and b. In Mo-SiO2 catalyst, binding energies of 235.7 and 232.6 eV typically corresponded to Mo 3d3/2 and Mo 3d5/2 were observed, indicating that Mo element had a valence state of +6. However, the valence state of Mo changed significantly after doping with Cs element, where Mo in low valence state could be clearly observed in MoCs-SiO2. The mixed-valence of Mo species were found at 234.4, 231.2, 232.6 and 229.4 eV, attributed to Mo5+ 3d3/2, Mo5+ 3d5/2, Mo4+ 3d3/2 and Mo4+ 3d5/2, respectively [43]. It is clear that the introduction of Cs induced the formation of reduced valence state of Mo species. This was also confirmed by Cs 3d spectra, where a shift of peaks to higher binding energy was noticed, indicating that Cs species supplied electrons to Mo and resulting in a higher electron cloud density surrounding Mo, namely, partially reduced Mo species [44,45]. Accordingly, the H2-TPR results showed that MoCs-SiO2 had a lower reduction temperature in the range of 260–510 °C (Fig. 2c), which can be ascribed to the reduction of Mo6+ to Mo4+ [46–48]. The lowered reduction temperature indicated that Mo species in MoCs-SiO2 was easier to be reduced, which can be attributed to the supplied electrons from Cs. This phenomenon was also observed when Cs was incorporated with other transition metals, such as Ru and Fe, the electron-supplying behaviour of Cs led to a valence change of the main active metals [49,50]. In MoCs-SiO2 catalyst, the contents of Mo6+, Mo5+ and Mo4+ were 58.5 %, 15.4 % and 26.1 %, respectively. It has been widely reported that the coordinatively unsaturated or reduced valence state tungsten (W) was pivotal for C−C bond cleavage during the transformation of glucose [32,51–53]. Considering that W and Mo belong to the same main group and have similar chemical properties, it can be reasonably concluded that the partially reduced Mo species could facilitate the C−C bond cleavage of glucose. The Py-FTIR spectra of Mo-based catalysts showed characteristic peaks around 1450 cm−1 (Fig. 2d), which was assigned to Lewis acid sites and attributed to the interaction of pyridine with coordinatively unsaturated cation centres. Meanwhile, no obvious band of pyridine adsorption on Brønsted acid sites (1540 cm−1) was observed in the spectra [54], indicating that the Mo-based catalysts exhibited predominantly Lewis acidity. The low proportion of Brønsted acid sites was beneficial in avoiding side reactions of glucose such as direct dehydration. The amount of Lewis acid sites increased from 24.7 μmol·g−1 to 32.3 μmol·g−1 when Cs was introduced, implying the increased content of coordinatively unsaturated Mo centres on the surface of MoCs-SiO2. In addition, the obvious shift of peaks related to Lewis acid sites also indicated the presence of different Mo species. This was consistent with the high proportion of low valence state Mo species indicated by XPS and the good dispersion of Mo species. The increased Lewis acidity was conducive to the RAC of glucose due to the intrinsic stable nature of C−C bonds. 3.2 Catalytic performance The catalytic performance of Mo-based catalyst was investigated (Tables 1 and S2). Control experiment conducted with SiO2 support or without catalyst gave neglectable amounts of acetylfurans (Table S3). At 110 °C, the catalytic conversion of glucose over Mo-SiO2 gave 13.7 % of MAF and 20 % of DMAF as the target products, along with 32.4 % of C-glycosylfuran and small amount of mannose (Table 1, entry 1). The results indicated that glucose underwent [C2+C4] RAC reaction to produce C2 glycolaldehyde and C4 erythrose, which subsequently reacted with acac to form MAF and DMAF, respectively. The formation of mannose clearly indicated the epimerization of glucose, where the 1,2-intramolecular carbon shift was involved [29]. In addition to C−C bond cleavage, it is noteworthy that the direct C−C coupling of glucose with acac catalysed by Lewis acidic Mo gave C-glycosylfuran as the major product (Garcia Gonzalez reaction). This by-product was formed by the nucleophilic addition of acac with an active α-H to the carbonyl group of glucose, followed by the elimination of two molecules of water [55]. It can be seen that three primary reactions including the RAC reaction, epimerization and Garcia Gonzalez reaction co-existed during the transformation of glucose over Mo-SiO2, leading to a low selectivity of MAF and DMAF. Thus, the promotion of C−C bond cleavage of glucose is paramount towards MAF and DMAF production. The catalytic performance of different metal ions incorporated on Mo-SiO2 was investigated (Table 1, entries 2–3). The addition of alkaline-earth metals (Ba2+ and Ca2+) showed a negative effect in terms of glucose conversion and products yields. Both MoBa-SiO2 and MoCa-SiO2 were inactive for the production of acetylfuranic compounds. However, the incorporation of alkali metals into Mo-SiO2 markedly enhanced the activity. More importantly, over 25.7 % of MAF and 37.2 % of DMAF were obtained with bimetallic catalysts, and the total carbon yield exceeded 62.9 % compared to 33.7 % from Mo-SiO2. The catalytic activity followed the order of Cs > K > Na > Li (Table 1, entries 4–7). The stronger the alkalinity, the higher the yields of furanic products. MoCs-SiO2 exhibited the best catalytic performance, resulting in 31.2 % of MAF and 43 % of DMAF (110 °C, 120 min), whereas the direct C−C coupling product C-glycosylfuran was not detected. The introduction of Cs significantly promoted the C−C bond cleavage of glucose. In addition, transition metals such as Co and Ni could also facilitate the C-C bond cleavage of glucose, but slightly less efficiently than Cs (Fig. S20). The effect of the content of Cs was further studied by varying the molar ratio of Mo and Cs (Table 1, entries 7–12). The conversion of glucose increased with the increasing of Cs content, along with an obvious decrease on the yields of C-glycosylfuran. The incorporation of Cs clearly alters the selectivity of the reaction, with the cleavage of C-C bond dominating. The yield of mannose showed a volcano-type tendency, whereas that of MAF and DAMF constantly increased and reaching the highest yield at a Mo/Cs ratio of 1:1. This indicated that Cs could promote the epimerization of glucose, while the further increase of Cs content could also catalyse the RAC of mannose to form C2/C4 intermediates, thereby improving the yields and selectivities of MAF and DMAF. Notably, in the absence of Mo, the Cs-SiO2 gave only 5.7 % of MAF, along with a low glucose conversion of 58.1 % (Table 1, entry 13). This suggested that Mo remained the main active species. As a promoter, the addition of Cs improved the dispersion of Mo species, induced the formation of partially reduced Mo, increased the Lewis acidity and thus contributed to the selective [C2+C4] C−C bond cleavage of glucose. The effect of reaction temperature (Fig. 3 a) on product distribution over MoCs-SiO2 were further explored. MAF and DMAF with low yields could be obtained even at 70 °C and the yields increased sharply to 25.8 % and 37.7 % at 90 °C. As the temperature raised to 130 °C, the product yields continued to increase, reaching a maximum of 32.8 % and 48.6 %, respectively. The theoretical carbon yields of MAF and DMAF from glucose is 33.3 % and 66.6 %. From this aspect, the glucose-cleaved product C2 glycolaldehyde could selectively transformed into MAF (98.4 %), whereas C4 erythrose formed DMAF in a relative low selectivity (73 %). This is likely due to the highly reactivity of glycolaldehyde itself, which subjected to rapid nucleophilic addition with acac. The temperature at which RAC of glucose occurred in the present study was much lower than that usually reported (> 160 °C), suggesting that MoCs-SiO2 was able to reduce the activation energy for C−C bond cleavage. When the temperature was further increased to 170 °C, the yield of MAF increased slightly, but a sharp decrease in DMAF yield was observed. This phenomenon was in line with our previous report that DMAF was unstable at high temperatures. The effect of catalyst dosage on the catalytic conversion of glucose was evaluated (Fig. S21). At a low loading of 2.7 wt%, only 15.1 % of acetylfurans could be obtained, along with mannose yield of 7 %, C-glycosylfuran yield of 31.7 % and glucose conversion of 84.8 %. The yields of mannose and C-glycosylfuran decreased with the increasing amount of MoCs-SiO2, whereas the yield of acetylfurans constantly increased and reached the maximum at the loading of 50 mg (27.7 wt%). Further increasing the amount of catalyst showed no increasement on the yields of MAF and DMAF. The results showed that 50 mg was the optimal dosage for effective cleavage of C-C bonds of glucose under the applied conditions. The presence of acac is essential to capture the intermediates. The effect of different ratio of acac and H2O on the yield of acetylfurans was then investigated (Fig. 3b). The yield of acetylfurans remained almost the same (76.8 %-81.4 %) in the acac:H2O ratio range from 7:3 to 3:7. Nevertheless, only 11.3 % of acetylfurans was obtained when pure acetylacetone was employed. Proper amount of H2O is beneficial to the dissolution of glucose and the generation of homogeneous reaction medium for the catalytic process as reported previously [26]. However, when the amount of acac decreased to 1 mL, an obvious decrease of yield to 45.6 % and the formation of humins were noticed. This is most likely due to the reduced capacity to capture intermediates in a timely manner when the amount of acac is low, resulting in side reactions in aqueous phase. Additionally, substrate concentration is an important factor in terms of industrial feasibility. A total acetylfurans yield of 81.4 % was obtained at a glucose concentration of 36 g/L. Although this value gradually decreased along with the increase of glucose concentration (Fig. 3c), a satisfactory total yield of 60 % (26.1 % of MAF and 33.8 % of DMAF) could still be maintained at a fairly high concentration of 180 g/L, demonstrating the high catalytic activity of MoCs-SiO2 catalyst. As acac served both as a solvent and a reactant in this transformation, its reuse was also considered in the reusability test for sustainable purpose. Regarding this, the recycle experiments was conducted by a facile method, where the whole reaction system was reused without separation. After each reaction, fresh glucose substrate (same amount as in the first reaction) was added into the reaction solution for the next run. As shown in Fig. 3d, the yields of MAF and DMAF remained relativity stable after six runs (74.2 % vs. 64.7 %). The XRD pattern of spent material showed no obvious diffraction peaks of MoO3 as the fresh catalyst (Fig. S22a). Similarly, no obvious change of functional groups was observed in FTIR spectra (Fig. S22b). The Raman spectra of spent material was also measured and no peaks corresponding to orthorhombic MoO3 were noticed, especially the characteristic stretching vibration of Mo-O-Mo bridge bonds at 818 cm−1 (Fig. S23). XPS results showed that the electronic state of Mo and Cs in spent material was similar to the fresh MoCs-SiO2 catalyst (Fig. S24). In addition, the H2-TPR of spent material also showed a lower reduction temperature for Mo species (Fig. S25), in accord with XPS observations. However, Py-FTIR showed a small loss of acidic sites in the spent material (Fig. S26). In summary, the stability of the spent material is relatively good based on the above characterizations. The slight decrease in yields could be attributed to the accumulated products affecting the interaction between glucose and the catalyst. More importantly, the above strategy also provides a cost-effective approach to efficiently recover products after recycle due to their high concentrations. 3.3 Kinetic studies and proposed reaction pathways The initial reaction rates of glucose conversion and products formation were studied to compare the intrinsic activity of Mo-SiO2 and MoCs-SiO2 (Fig. 4 a). The initial reaction rate of glucose over MoCs-SiO2 reached 3023 μmol·gcat −1 min−1, which was 1.2-fold higher than that of Mo-SiO2 catalyst (2465 μmol·gcat −1 min−1). Accordingly, the formation rates of MAF and DMAF were also significantly increased by the introduction of Cs, which were 3.3 and 3.4-fold higher than those of Mo-SiO2, respectively. Moreover, the static adsorption of glucose was conducted (Fig. 4b). The adsorption amount of glucose on MoCs-SiO2 catalyst was 1.3 times higher than that of Mo-SiO2. Nevertheless, neglectable amount of glucose was absorbed on the sole Cs-SiO2. Meanwhile, a low conversion of glucose and only 5.7 % of MAF was obtained when using Cs-SiO2 as the catalyst. This further demonstrated that Cs was not the active species of the reaction and only served as a promoter. The addition of Cs enhanced the adsorption of glucose molecules by altering the chemical state and dispersion of the active Mo species, which was essential for the subsequent transformations, thereby accelerating the generation of MAF and DMAF. To further explore the effect of Cs incorporation, the kinetic behaviours of glucose conversion to MAF and DMAF over a time course under different reaction temperatures were investigated over Mo-SiO2 and MoCs-SiO2 (Fig. 5 ). A parallel reaction kinetic model was established according to the features that intermediates C2 glycolaldehyde and C4 erythrose formed simultaneously upon the C−C bond cleavage of glucose. The experimental results were fitted to the following equations: (6) d C G l u c o s e d t = − ( k 1 + k 2 ) C G l u c o s e (7) d C M A F d t = k 1 C G l u c o s e (8) d C D M A F d t = k 2 C G l u c o s e where k1 and k2 represent the reaction rate constant of MAF and DMAF formation on MoCs-SiO2 catalyst, and CGlucose, CMAF and CDMAF are the real-time concentrations of glucose, MAF and DMAF, respectively. As shown in Fig. 5, the conversion of glucose and the yields of MAF and DMAF increased gradually with the prolonged reaction time and elevated temperatures. The formation of MAF and DMAF was largely accelerated by MoCs-SiO2, especially at low temperature, indicating the enhanced capacity for C−C bond cleavage. The reaction rate constants of MAF and DMAF production over MoCs-SiO2 (k’) were at least 2.6 times higher than that over Mo-SiO2 (k) at different temperatures (Table S4). According to the Arrhenius plots (Fig. 5e and i), the calculated apparent activation energies of MAF and DMAF production from glucose was 36.9 and 38.8 kJ/mol over MoCs-SiO2, while Mo-SiO2-catalyzed transformation required higher activation energies of 51.4 and 52.9 kJ/mol, respectively. This further demonstrated the positive effect of Cs addition on reducing the apparent activation energy of C-C bond cleavage, thereby facilitating the formation of furanic products, in accord with the enhanced adsorption of glucose. The kinetic results were in good agreement with the promoter effect of Cs on the catalytic performance. The calculated reaction rate constants for the formation of MAF and DMAF were almost the same, both over Mo-SiO2 and MoCs-SiO2 catalysts (Table S4), which further supported the proposed kinetic model that the generation of MAF and DMAF were parallel. After the addition of Cs, the reaction rate constants of MAF and DMAF increased almost in the same proportion at each temperature, which further indicated that Cs could selectively promote the C−C bond cleavage without promoting other side reactions. During the Mo-SiO2-catalyzed conversion of glucose, in addition to C−C bond cleavage, C-glycosylfuran generated by the Garcia-Gonzalez reaction were also formed, and its amount gradually increased with reaction time and temperature. A high yield up to 50 % could be obtained 130 °C, 150 min (Fig. S27). In the meantime, no dehydration product such as 5-hydroxymethylfurfural was detected during the catalytic process. This could be attributed to the low amount of Brønsted acid sites. Additionally, the mild reaction conditions (≤ 130 °C) also avoided the temperature range generally required for 5-hydroxymethylfurfural formation (≥ 130 °C in aqueous phase) [56]. The Lewis acid sites was responsible for both C−C bond cleavage and coupling reactions. Distinct difference was presented that no C-glycosylfuran could be detected when MoCs-SiO2 with higher Lewis acidity was employed at all temperatures. This suggested that Cs has a strong promoting effect on the RAC of glucose, leading to a shift in reaction selectivity from C−C coupling to C−C bond cleavage. In addition to the above transformations, the epimerization of glucose to mannose occurred both on Mo-SiO2 or MoCs-SiO2 catalysts. The amount of mannose was firstly increased and then decreased with the prolonged reaction time at all temperatures (Fig. 6 a and b). High temperature favoured the formation of mannose, where the highest mannose yield of 24.7 % was obtained at 130 °C in only 5 min over Mo-SiO2. The decreased tendency of mannose indicated its further transformation under the applied conditions. Mannose as an epimer of glucose processes the same features that its C2−C3 bond is facile to cleave due to the presence of aldehyde group, where glycolaldehyde and erythrose are formed and also lead to the formation of MAF and DMAF. To further verify the contribution of epimerization and whether glucose must first be epimerized to mannose before proceeding to C−C bond cleavage, the catalytic conversion of mannose as a substrate was investigated. As can be seen in Fig. 6c, the initial reaction rate for mannose formation was 958 and 820 μmol gcat −1 min−1 over Mo-SiO2 or MoCs-SiO2, respectively, which implied that doping with Cs had no positive effect on the epimerization of glucose to mannose. To further prove this, the epimerization of glucose was conducted in aqueous solution without acac. It was found that the 1,2-intramolecular carbon shift between glucose and mannose reached equilibrium quickly and the yield of mannose over Mo-SiO2 and MoCs-SiO2 was basically the same (Fig. S28). The initial formation rates of MAF and DMAF from mannose over MoCs-SiO2 were 1237 and 1113 μmol gcat −1 min−1, respectively, which were slightly lower than that from glucose (1501 and 1255 μmol gcat −1 min−1), implying that mannose was not an essential intermediate. Nevertheless, the yields of MAF and DMAF derived from mannose were comparable with that from glucose under the same reaction conditions (Fig. 6d), indicating that the selectivity of acetylfurans was not affected by the epimerization reaction. More importantly, Cs also clearly promoted the C−C bond cleavage of mannose compared to Mo-SiO2 catalyst. On the basis of the above results and discussion, the reaction pathway for glucose conversion to MAF and DMAF over MoCs-SiO2 was proposed (Fig. 7 ). To determine the interaction of glucose and the catalyst, the FTIR spectra of glucose adsorbed onto MoCs-SiO2 was measured (Fig. 7a). It can be noticed that glucose itself showed no characteristic peak for aldehyde group, which indicated that glucose existed in cyclic forms. However, when glucose was contacted with the MoCs-SiO2 catalyst, a distinct absorption peak at 1660 cm−1 appeared, indicating that there was an interaction between the aldehyde groups of glucose and MoCs-SiO2. Glucose aqueous solution are enriched in cyclic α- and β-pyranoses, which undergoes ring opening reaction to form acyclic structures [57,58]. The interaction between glucose and the catalyst occurs under the applied conditions, where Mo sites binds with the O atom of the CO group in glucose, resulting in a polarized CO bond as illustrated in Fig. 7a. Subsequently, the C−C bond cleavage of glucose produces C2 glycolaldehyde and C4 erythrose as the intermediates, which are captured by acac to form furanic products MAF and DMAF through nucleophilic addition and dehydration (Fig. 7b). The absence of glycolaldehyde and erythrose during the whole transformation suggests that they react rapidly with acac, which in turn drives the C−C bond cleavage of glucose. This direct C−C bond cleavage of glucose is the major reaction pathway. In addition, glucose can undergo epimerization to form mannose, which also undergoes C−C bond cleavage to ultimately produce MAF and DMAF, resulting in a higher carbon efficiency. Considering the small amount of mannose formed in this process, the above route accounts for only a small fraction of the overall pathway. Moreover, the C−C coupling reaction which forms C-glycosylfuran is inhibited over Cs promoted catalyst, resulting in high selectivity towards MAF and DMAF. 4 Conclusions A facile catalytic system was developed for the direct conversion of glucose to new type of furanic products in green H2O/acac medium using MoCs-SiO2 as the catalyst. On the basis of pristine Mo-SiO2, the introduction of Cs largely reduced the particle size of active Mo species and improved its dispersion. Cs also induced the formation of partially reduced Mo species and increased the Lewis acidity of the catalyst, thereby promoted the C−C bond cleavage of glucose. The produced intermediates C2 glycolaldehyde and C4 erythrose subsequently reacted with acac to give furans. As a result, higher yields of MAF and DMAF (81.4 %) was achieved compared to that of Mo-SiO2 (35.8 %) under applied reaction conditions (130 °C, 120 min). The formation of direct C−C coupling product C6-glycosylfuran was inhibited over MoCs-SiO2, while the epimerization of glucose to mannose also contributed to a small portion of the high selectivity of MAF and DMAF. The developed method efficiently converts glucose into high value-added acetylfuran compounds with high carbon efficiency, providing new perspectives for the development of future carbohydrate-based biorefining. coredata.dc:description: Furans are important scaffolds with applications in pharmaceuticals, polymers synthesis and biofuels. The direct production of new types of furans from glucose is therefore significant but remains a great challenge. Herein, we report a facile strategy to produce acetylfurans directly from glucose over MoCs-SiO2, with an increase in yield from 35.8 % to 81.4 % compared with pristine Mo-SiO2 due to the facilitated C−C bond cleavage of glucose. The incorporation of Cs improved the dispersion of Mo species, induced the formation of partially reduced Mo, increased the Lewis acidity and glucose adsorption of the catalyst, and thus shifting the reaction selectivity from C−C coupling to cleavage. Kinetic studies further demonstrated the positive contribution of Cs as a promoter in lowering the activation energy of C−C bond cleavage. This study provides a promising strategy to broaden the range of furanic compounds derived from glucose for product-oriented biorefineries.
